Objective.LearningContext: Create a lesson plan for an educator with Senior experience, to be used in a School context, for a Large group of learners on a Beginner level.
TextLearningObjectives: Learners will be able to explain the concept of programming language in their own words.
Learners will be able to interpret the implications of mobile phone settings for surveillance purposes.

Path.TitleLearningPath: 1000 Cell Phones: A Mobile Media Installation

LessonPlan.Description: Provide an overview of the 1000 Cell Phones Installation, explaining how it visualizes and animates discovered Bluetooth devices within its situated space.
Explain how devices are represented as abstract discs in dimensional screen space, colored by transcribing the devices' unique identifiers to distinctive tone and hue values.

Discuss how discovered device names animate across the screens, emphasizing the transient nature of the tracking devices we carry, unwittingly broadcasting a unique identifier for anyone or anything willing to listen.

Explain how the installation is installed in a social space, such as a café or lobby, to capture the unseen dialogue between mobile phones and laptops broadcasting their Bluetooth identities while owners lurk and socialize.
Discuss how participants often engage in the intervention by altering their device settings to affect the textual content on the visualization.
Explain the concept of programming language in simple terms, using examples to help the Learners understand.
Interpret the implications of mobile phone settings for surveillance purposes, discussing how certain settings can be used to track and monitor individuals.
Final Assessment

TextLearningObjectives: Learners will be able to explain the concept of programming language in their own words.

Path.TitleLearningPath: Working with IndexedDB in TypeScript React

LessonPlan.Description: Explanation of what IndexedDB is and how it can be used for client-side storage of structured data.
Step-by-step guide on how to create a database in IndexedDB and start creating tables.
Explanation of basic CRUD operations in IndexedDB, including getValue, getAllValue, putValue, putBulkValue, and deleteValue.
Demonstration of how to use the IndexedDB class in a React application, including how to check IndexedDB in the browser.
IndexedDB Quiz

Path.TitleLearningPath: Credibility and Trustworthiness of Online Sources

LessonPlan.Description: Explanation of the theories of online credibility, including Fogg and Tseng's theory of computer credibility and the key dimensions of credibility: trustworthiness and expertise.
The problem of assessing the credibility of online information due to the lack of traditional cues of expertise and authority.
Studies show that youth perceive information without identified authors as credible, especially if some sort of collective judgment of the information is available.
Introduction of a new theory of online credibility evaluation called aggregated trustworthiness, based on social dynamics and online navigational practices.
The three main factors of aggregated trustworthiness are social validation, profile, and authority & trustee, which are dependent on each other and are vetted into a larger system of navigation.
Assessment: Credibility Evaluation

Path.TitleLearningPath: Credibility and Trustworthiness of Online Sources

LessonPlan.Description: Explanation of several theories of online credibility, including Fogg and Tseng's theory of computer credibility, and the development of a new theory to address changes in technological reach and online practices.
Identification of the two key dimensions of credibility according to Fogg and Tseng's theory: trustworthiness and expertise.
Comparison of aggregated trustworthiness to traditional source evaluation, including the use of trustworthiness and expertise cues to establish credibility.
LessonPlan.Topic: Aggregated Trustworthiness vs. Traditional Source Evaluation

LessonPlan.Description: Aggregated Trustworthiness
The problem of assessing the credibility of online information due to the lack of traditional cues of expertise and authority.
Studies show that youth perceive information without identified authors as credible, especially if some sort of collective judgment of the information is available.
Credibility Evaluation

The theory of aggregated trustworthiness explains a dynamic unique to the Web, where social validation, authority and trustee, and navigation processes are used to assess the credibility of online information.

The largescale verifications made by others, such as comments, Facebook Likes, shares, social bookmarks, ratings, etc., provide social validation and increase the perceived credibility of online information.
Aggregated Trustworthiness
Having a known identity can be critical when assessing important information online. Profiles provide the baseline for identity online as well as adding a fixture of the evaluation.
Known brands or authorities on the matter, as well as trustees verifying lesser-known sources, are important fixtures in the evaluation process and the overall dynamic of establishing credibility.
Aggregated Trustworthiness
The navigation process itself affects the perceived credibility by highlighting search rankings, topic correlations, and brand exposure.

Wikipedia is a prime example of how aggregated trustworthiness works, where the vast majority of the editors and contributors are anonymous, yet the sum of their edits and re-edits seems to justify the inherent lack of root authority and identity.
Aggregated Trustworthiness

WikiTrust is an algorithm developed to counter the criticism of Wikipedia's credibility by color-coding every word in every article based on the reliability of its author and the length of time the edit has persisted on the page.
Explanation of the WikiTrust algorithm and how it aggregates trustworthiness to evaluate the credibility of online information.
Assessment: Evaluating Online Sources

Objective.LearningContext: Create a lesson plan for an educator with Intermediate experience, to be used in a University context, for a Large group of learners on a Intermediate level.
TextLearningObjectives: Students will be able to create indicators to evaluate the credibility of an online resource.

Path.TitleLearningPath: Credibility and Trustworthiness of Online Sources

LessonPlan.Description: Explanation of several theories of online credibility, including Fogg and Tseng's theory of computer credibility, and the development of a new theory to address changes in technological reach and online practices.
Identification of the two key dimensions of credibility according to Fogg and Tseng's theory: trustworthiness and expertise.
Comparison of aggregated trustworthiness to traditional source evaluation, including the use of trustworthiness and expertise cues to establish credibility.
LessonPlan.Topic: Aggregated Trustworthiness vs. Traditional Source Evaluation

LessonPlan.Description: Creating Indicators to Evaluate the Credibility of an Online Resource
LessonPlan.Topic: Creating Indicators to Evaluate the Credibility of an Online Resource

LessonPlan.Description: The problem of assessing the credibility of online information due to the lack of traditional cues of expertise and authority.
Studies show that youth perceive information without identified authors as credible, especially if some sort of collective judgment of the information is available.
Evaluating the Credibility of Online Information
LessonPlan.Topic: Evaluating the Credibility of Online Information

LessonPlan.Description: The theory of aggregated trustworthiness explains a dynamic unique to the Web, where social validation, authority and trustee, and navigation processes are used to assess the credibility of online information.

The largescale verifications made by others, such as comments, Facebook Likes, shares, social bookmarks, ratings, etc., provide social validation and increase the perceived credibility of online information.
Having a known identity can be critical when assessing important information online. Profiles provide the baseline for identity online as well as adding a fixture of the evaluation.
Known brands or authorities on the matter, as well as trustees verifying lesser-known sources, are important fixtures in the evaluation process and the overall dynamic of establishing credibility.
The navigation process itself affects the perceived credibility by highlighting search rankings, topic correlations, and brand exposure.
Assessment: Evaluating the Credibility of Online Information
LessonPlan.Topic: Assessment: Evaluating the Credibility of Online Information

Objective.LearningContext: Create a lesson plan for an educator with Intermediate experience, to be used in a University context, for a Large group of learners on a Intermediate level.
TextLearningObjectives: Students will be able to understand what credibility means with regard to online resources
Students will be able to infer the key elements of the credibility of online resources

Introduction of a new theory of online credibility evaluation called aggregated trustworthiness, based on social dynamics and online navigational practices.
Aggregated trustworthiness is dependent on social validation, authority and trustee cues, and the navigation process.
Comparison of aggregated trustworthiness to traditional source evaluation, including the use of trustworthiness and expertise cues to establish credibility.
LessonPlan.Topic: Aggregated Trustworthiness vs. Traditional Source Evaluation

LessonPlan.Description: Assessment: Evaluating Online Sources

LessonPlan.Description: Explain the types of materials included in the World Digital Library collection, such as books, manuscripts, maps, newspapers, journals, prints, photographs, sound recordings, and films.

Discuss the availability of the World Digital Library metadata in seven languages and the presentation of primary materials in their original languages, including many lesser-known and endangered languages.
Provide an overview of the establishment of the World Digital Library project, including the involvement of the US Library of Congress, UNESCO, and partner institutions worldwide.
LessonPlan.Topic: History of the World Digital Library Project

LessonPlan.Description: Explain the guidelines set by the World Digital Library Content Selection Committee for selecting content based on cultural and historical importance, with recognition of the achievements of all countries and cultures over a wide range of time periods.

Discuss the challenges faced by the World Digital Library project, including the lack of digitized cultural content in many countries, poorly developed search and display functions on existing websites, and the need for multilingual access.
LessonPlan.Topic: Challenges Faced by the World Digital Library Project

LessonPlan.Description: Provide an overview of the launch of the World Digital Library collection in 2009, the addition of content and new partners, and the adoption of the WDL Charter in 2010 to establish a permanent governance structure.
LessonPlan.Topic: Launch and Expansion of the World Digital Library Collection

LessonPlan.Description: Explain the transition of the World Digital Library collection to a sustainable home for perpetual access on the Library of Congress's main website in 2021.
LessonPlan.Topic: Transition to the Library of Congress Website

LessonPlan.Description: Warn the Learners about an individual claiming to be the director of the World Digital Library and soliciting freelance work for a 200 employment ID, and clarify that the WDL's charter has ended and neither the Library of Congress nor the former World Digital Library has any connection with this scam.

Objective.LearningContext: Create a lesson plan for an educator with Intermediate experience, to be used in a University context, for a Large group of learners on a Intermediate level.
TextLearningObjectives: Learners will be able to develop a set of criteria to assess the credibility of a source.

Path.TitleLearningPath: Credibility and Trustworthiness of Online Sources

LessonPlan.Description: Explanation of the theories of online credibility, including Fogg and Tseng's theory of computer credibility and the key dimensions of credibility: trustworthiness and expertise.
The problem of assessing the credibility of online information due to the lack of traditional cues of expertise and authority.
The navigation process, social validation, and authority and trustee cues all affect the perceived credibility of online information.
Introduction of a new theory of online credibility evaluation called aggregated trustworthiness, based on social dynamics and online navigational practices.
Aggregated trustworthiness helps explain the success of a number of online platforms like Wikipedia, eBay, Twitter, LinkedIn, and many more.
Developing Criteria for Assessing Online Credibility
LessonPlan.Topic: Developing Criteria for Assessing Online Credibility

Objective.LearningContext:
Learning Scenario Title: Information Analysis Systems

Learning Objectives:

	•	Understand the use of information analysis systems for decision-making in the public sector.
	•	Evaluate the origin and structure of publicly available databases.
	•	Develop an indicator system to support decision-making within public institutions.

Learning Scenario Description:
This course, targeted at undergraduate students in Business Administration, is designed to provide a comprehensive understanding of information analysis systems in the context of public-sector decision-making. Throughout the sessions, students will learn to evaluate and utilize government data sources, understand the origin and structure of public databases, and develop indicator systems that support informed decision-making in public institutions.

Combining theory with practice, the course offers in-person classes where students engage with theoretical presentations, key reading materials, case study analyses, and hands-on activities. Teaching tools will include multimedia presentations, instructional videos, and brainstorming sessions to encourage active comprehension. Students will have access to government open-data repositories, enabling real-time application of the concepts covered. Additionally, the course will integrate Open Educational Resources (OER) to enhance learning and analytical skills.

By the end of the course, students will be equipped to understand the application of information analysis systems in decision-making, evaluate data sources, and develop strategic indicators within public contexts—fundamental skills for future careers in public administration and organizational management. This learning scenario aims to prepare students with essential competencies for a data-driven decision-making environment.

Integration of ENCORE:
In this course, the instructor will use the ENCORE platform to enrich course content with Open Educational Resources (OER) that complement practical, applied learning in information analysis for decision-making. Through ENCORE, the instructor will seek specific resources such as case studies, practical guides for creating indicators, and examples of data analysis in the public sector.

ENCORE will enable the instructor to plan and update the course with an open educational approach, ensuring that materials are accessible, relevant, and aligned with course objectives. Students will benefit from the variety of available resources, supporting autonomous learning and the practice of key skills like information analysis within open-data repositories, essential for their studies in Business Administration.
TextLearningObjectives: Understand the use of information analysis systems for decision-making in the public sector.
Evaluate the origin and structure of publicly available databases.
Develop an indicator system to support decision-making within public institutions.

Objective.LearningContext:
What is a computer?
A computer is an electronic device that manipulates information, or data. It has the ability to store, retrieve, and process data. You may already know that you can use a computer to type documents, send email, play games, and browse the Web. You can also use it to edit or create spreadsheets, presentations, and even videos.

What is Data?
Data is a collection of raw, unorganised facts and details like text, observations, figures, symbols and descriptions of things etc. In other words, data does not carry any specific purpose and has no significance by itself. Moreover, data is measured in terms of bits and bytes – which are basic units of information in the context of computer storage and processing.

What is Information?
Information is processed, organised and structured data. It provides context for data and enables decision making. For example, a single customer’s sale at a restaurant is data – this becomes information when the business is able to identify the most popular or least popular dish.

Frequently Asked Questions
Q1
What is data? Explain with an example.
Data is raw, unorganized, unprocessed information. E.g., the information collected for writing a research paper is data until it is presented in an organized manner.

Q2
What is information?
Information is the processed, organized data that is beneficial in providing useful knowledge. For eg., the data compiled in an organized way in a research paper provides information about a particular concept/ topic.

Q3
What is valid information?
Valid information is something that is reliable. The information that has been checked and verified for a purpose is a valid information.

Q4
What are the different types of data?
Data can be of two types:

Qualitative data: It is non-numerical data. For eg., the texture of the skin, the colour of the eyes, etc.
Quantitative data: Quantitative data is given in numbers. Data in the form of questions such as “how much” and “how many”, gives the quantitative data.

What is Hardware?
Hardware is any part of your computer that has a physical structure, such as the keyboard or mouse. It also includes all of the computer's internal parts.

What is Software?
Software is any set of instructions that tells the hardware what to do and how to do it. 

What are the different types of computers?
When most people hear the word computer, they think of a personal computer such as a desktop or laptop. However, computers come in many shapes and sizes, and they perform many different functions in our daily lives. When you withdraw cash from an ATM, scan groceries at the store, or use a calculator, you're using a type of computer.

What are the main functions of computers?
Computers play a role in every field of life. They are used in homes, business, educational institutions, research organizations, medical field, government offices, entertainment, etc.

Home
Computers are used at homes for several purposes like online bill payment, watching movies or shows at home, home tutoring, social media access, playing games, internet access, etc. They provide communication through electronic mail. They help to avail work from home facility for corporate employees. Computers help the student community to avail online educational support.

Medical Field
Computers are used in hospitals to maintain a database of patients’ history, diagnosis, X-rays, live monitoring of patients, etc. Surgeons nowadays use robotic surgical devices to perform delicate operations, and conduct surgeries remotely. Virtual reality technologies are also used for training purposes. It also helps to monitor the fetus inside the mother’s womb.

Entertainment
Computers help to watch movies online, play games online; act as a virtual entertainer in playing games, listening to music, etc. MIDI instruments greatly help people in the entertainment industry in recording music with artificial instruments. Videos can be fed from computers to full screen televisions. Photo editors are available with fabulous features.

Industry
Computers are used to perform several tasks in industries like managing inventory, designing purpose, creating virtual sample products, interior designing, video conferencing, etc. Online marketing has seen a great revolution in its ability to sell various products to inaccessible corners like interior or rural areas. Stock markets have seen phenomenal participation from different levels of people through the use of computers.

Education
Computers are used in education sector through online classes, online examinations, referring e-books, online tutoring, etc. They help in increased use of audio-visual aids in the education field.

Government
In government sectors, computers are used in data processing, maintaining a database of citizens and supporting a paperless environment. The country’s defense organizations have greatly benefitted from computers in their use for missile development, satellites, rocket launches, etc.

Banking
In the banking sector, computers are used to store details of customers and conduct transactions, such as withdrawal and deposit of money through ATMs. Banks have reduced manual errors and expenses to a great extent through extensive use of computers.

Business
Nowadays, computers are totally integrated into business. The main objective of business is transaction processing, which involves transactions with suppliers, employees or customers. Computers can make these transactions easy and accurate. People can analyze investments, sales, expenses, markets and other aspects of business using computers.

Training
Many organizations use computer-based training to train their employees, to save money and improve performance. Video conferencing through computers allows saving of time and travelling costs by being able to connect people in various locations.

Arts
Computers are extensively used in dance, photography, arts and culture. The fluid movement of dance can be shown live via animation. Photos can be digitized using computers.

Science and Engineering
Computers with high performance are used to stimulate dynamic process in Science and Engineering. Supercomputers have numerous applications in area of Research and Development (R&D). Topographic images can be created through computers. Scientists use computers to plot and analyze data to have a better understanding of earthquakes.

What do you mean by informatics?
Informatics is the study, design, and development of information technology that generates, stores, processes, and presents information. Often, informatics is referred to as the science of information.

Path.TitleLearningPath: Failed to retrieve the PDF file

LessonPlan.Description: Студенттерден PDF файлдарын алу процесі туралы лекцияны тыңдауды сұраңыз, 303 статус коды сияқты жалпы қателерге және олардың салдарына назар аударыңыз.
Студенттерден HTTP статус кодтары туралы бөлімді оқуды сұраңыз, әсіресе 303 статус коды мен оның веб-сұраулар контекстіндегі мағынасына назар аударыңыз.
Студенттерден PDF файл алу сәтсіз болған сценарийді талдауды сұраңыз, қателердің құрамдас бөліктерін бөлшектеп, ықтимал шешімдерді анықтаңыз.
Студенттерден берілген мәтіннен файл алу қателеріне қатысты кілт сөздерді, мысалы, 'статус коды', 'қайта бағыттау' және 'қате өңдеу' сияқты терминдерді анықтауды сұраңыз.
Студенттерден PDF файлдарын алу мәселелерін шешу және түзету үшін стратегиялар тізімін жасауды сұраңыз, URL-дерді және сервер жауаптарын тексеруді қоса.
Студенттерден алу қателерінің пайдаланушы тәжірибесіне және деректерге қолжетімділікке әсері туралы дебатқа қатысуды сұраңыз, өз аргументтерін қолдау үшін негізгі концепцияларды пайдаланыңыз.
Студенттерден PDF алу процесін симуляциялайтын жобаны аяқтауды, кездескен қателерді құжаттауды және өз талдауларына негізделген шешімдерді ұсынуды сұраңыз.

Objective.LearningContext: Create a lesson plan for an educator with Intermediate experience, to be used in a School context, for a Medium group of learners on a Beginner level.

Path.TitleLearningPath: The Future of Coal in a Carbon-Constrained World

LessonPlan.Description: Ask the students to listen to a lecture on the role of coal in a carbon-constrained world, explaining key concepts such as its impact on energy production and climate change.
LessonPlan.Topic: Role of Coal in a Carbon-Constrained World

LessonPlan.Description: Ask the students to read a chapter on the technologies and costs associated with coal-based power generation, focusing on carbon capture and sequestration.
LessonPlan.Topic: Technologies and Costs of Coal-Based Power Generation

LessonPlan.Description: Ask the students to create a list of the key reasons for managing carbon dioxide emissions from coal-based power generation.
LessonPlan.Topic: Importance of Carbon Dioxide Management from Coal

LessonPlan.Description: Ask the students to watch a video that highlights carbon capture and sequestration as a critical technology for reducing CO2 emissions from coal.
Ask the students to identify key terms and phrases from a text discussing the challenges and opportunities in coal-based power generation.
LessonPlan.Topic: Challenges and Opportunities in Coal-Based Power Generation

LessonPlan.Description: Ask the students to determine whether given statements about policy recommendations for coal use in a carbon-constrained world are true or false.
Ask the students to recall and list the major countries involved in global adherence to CO2 emission constraints, focusing on their roles.
LessonPlan.Topic: Global Adherence to CO2 Emission Constraints

LessonPlan.Description: Ask the students to provide examples of technologies that can enhance coal plant performance while reducing carbon emissions.
LessonPlan.Topic: Enhancing Coal Plant Performance in a Carbon-Constrained World

LessonPlan.Description: Ask the students to complete a project where they propose key changes to the Department of Energy RD&D program to promote CCS technologies.
LessonPlan.Topic: Department of Energy RD&D Program for CCS Technologies

Objective.LearningContext: Create a lesson plan for an educator with Intermediate experience, to be used in a University context, for a Large group of learners on a Intermediate level.
TextLearningObjectives: Students will be able to understand what credibility means with regard to online resources
Students will be able to infer the key elements of the credibility of online resources

Path.TitleLearningPath: Web Page Retrieval Failure

LessonPlan.Description: Ask the students to listen to a lecture explaining potential reasons for the failure to retrieve a web page, including server issues, network problems, and incorrect URLs.
Ask the students to read a guide on troubleshooting steps to resolve issues related to failed web page retrieval, covering methods such as checking internet connectivity and clearing browser cache.
Ask the students to summarize the key concepts related to web page retrieval failure, including common causes and troubleshooting techniques.
Ask the students to create a concept map that illustrates the relationships between different reasons for web page retrieval failure and the corresponding troubleshooting steps.
Ask the students to provide real-life examples of situations where web page retrieval failed and explain the reasons and solutions they applied.
Ask the students to complete a project where they simulate a web page retrieval failure scenario and document the troubleshooting steps they would take to resolve the issue.

Objective.LearningContext: Create a lesson plan for an educator with Intermediate experience, to be used in a University context, for a Small group of learners on a Intermediate level.
TextLearningObjectives: Learners will be able to explain the concept of digital humanities in their own words.
Learners will be able to interpret the impact of digital humanities on higher education.

Path.TitleLearningPath: Best Practices in Open Educational Resources: A Case Study

LessonPlan.Description: Ask the students to listen to a lecture on Open Educational Resources, explaining their definition, significance, and role in modern education.
Ask the students to read an article that outlines the advantages of using Open Educational Resources in teaching and learning.
Ask the students to participate in a discussion about the obstacles faced when integrating OER into educational practices.
Ask the students to summarize a specific case study that illustrates the practical application of Open Educational Resources.
Ask the students to identify key terms and concepts related to the benefits and challenges of OER from a provided text.
Ask the students to complete a project where they analyze a real-world case study of OER implementation, detailing its benefits, challenges, and outcomes.

Objective.LearningContext: This learning path is designed for public administration officers that develop website for disabled people.
TextLearningObjectives: create website using W3C and Wai-Aria

Path.TitleLearningPath: Frontend Website Design and Development Activity

LessonPlan.Description: Ask the students to create wireframes for a website frontend, demonstrating their understanding of layout and design principles.
Ask the students to discuss Ben Schneiderman's Eight Golden Rules and provide examples of how these principles can be applied in their own designs.
LessonPlan.Topic: Ben Schneiderman's Eight Golden Rules for Interface Design

LessonPlan.Description: Ask the students to conduct interviews with potential users to identify their needs and requirements for a website.
Ask the students to create user personas based on their interviews, illustrating different user types and their goals.
Ask the students to evaluate an existing website for accessibility, identifying areas for improvement to ensure inclusivity.
Ask the students to present their final website frontend project, demonstrating their application of design principles, user needs, and accessibility considerations.

Objective.LearningContext: This activity is designed for higher education students attending a course on educational assessment or instructional design. The scenario can be adapted to both in-person and blended learning environments.
TextLearningObjectives: Learners will be able to design an assessment rubric tailored to a specific learning task, demonstrating awareness of assessment criteria and learning outcomes.

Path.TitleLearningPath: Project LITE: Light Inquiry Through Experiments

LessonPlan.Description: Introduction to assessment rubrics
Ask the students to read about the LITE Spectrum Explorer 2.0 software, focusing on how it allows users to investigate the electromagnetic spectrum.
Ask the students to create a list of 3D models they can print to explore depth perception beyond 2D screens.
Ask the students to engage in a brainstorming session to generate ideas on how to use PDF images illustrating visual phenomena in their projects.
Ask the students to write a creative piece describing a fictional experiment using spinning tops on CDs and DVDs to create visual effects.
Ask the students to prepare a presentation on how binocular vision can be explored using apps on iPhones and iPods.
Ask the students to provide examples of how light aspects like fluorescence and color mixing can be explored using mobile apps.
Ask the students to troubleshoot and provide solutions for activating the Java plugin to run the Spectrum Explorer Applet on different operating systems.
Ask the students to complete a project where they design their own light experiment using concepts learned from Project LITE, presenting their findings to the class.
